title: English Grammar (Part I and Part II), English Vocabulary (Part III), English Reading Comprehension (Part IV)
what: This topic helps learners understand the rules of English grammar, build vocabulary, and improve reading comprehension.
tutorial: Use HTML to display examples, highlight rules, and explain each concept with basic formatting tags like <p>, <b>, <ol>, <ul>, and <table>.
steps:
1. Create an HTML page layout for grammar, vocabulary, and reading.
  2. Use <section> and <div> to separate parts.
  3. Display lessons using <p> and highlight key terms using <b>.
  4. Use <ul> or <ol> to present lists of words or steps.

sections.title: English Grammar - Part I
sections.what: This section introduces the basics of grammar: parts of speech and sentence types.
sections.tutorial: Use <p> tags to describe parts of speech and <table> to show examples.
sections.steps:
1. Create a paragraph for each part of speech.
  2. Use <table> to compare noun, verb, adjective, adverb.
  3. Give sample sentences using <p>.

sections.title: Parts of Speech
sections.what: These are types of words like nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs.
sections.tutorial: Display words in sentences using colored <span> to show what part of speech they are.
sections.steps:
1. Write a sentence like 'The cat runs fast.'
  2. Wrap 'cat' in blue (noun), 'runs' in green (verb), 'fast' in red (adverb).

sections.title: Types of Sentences
sections.what: Four types: declarative, interrogative, imperative, and exclamatory.
sections.tutorial: Use <p> to write an example of each sentence type.
sections.steps:
1. Write: 'I like pizza.' (declarative)
  2. 'Do you like pizza?' (interrogative)
  3. 'Eat the pizza!' (imperative)
  4. 'Wow, this pizza is great!' (exclamatory)

sections.title: English Grammar - Part II
sections.what: This part covers grammar rules like subject-verb agreement and tenses.
sections.tutorial: Use examples with <p> and highlight correct grammar usage using <b>.
sections.steps:
1. Write pairs of correct and incorrect sentences.
  2. Explain why one is correct using <p> and <ul>.

sections.title: Subject-Verb Agreement
sections.what: The verb must match the subject in number (singular/plural).
sections.tutorial: Write examples of correct and incorrect agreements in <p> tags.

sections.title: Tenses
sections.what: Verb tenses show time: past, present, and future.
sections.tutorial: Show same verb in different tenses using <table>.
sections.steps:
1. Use 'walk' as example.
  2. Create table with: walk, walked, will walk.
  3. Add sample sentences below each.

sections.title: English Vocabulary - Part III
sections.what: This section helps expand word knowledge and proper word usage.
sections.tutorial: Use <ul> and <dl> to show definitions and word groups.
sections.steps:
1. List new words using <ul>.
  2. Use <dl> for word and definition.
  3. Use <p> to show each word in a sentence.

sections.title: Synonyms and Antonyms
sections.what: Words with similar or opposite meanings help understand meaning and tone.
sections.tutorial: Use <table> to show synonyms and antonyms side by side.
sections.steps:
1. Create a table with 3 columns: Word, Synonym, Antonym.
  2. Fill with examples like 'happy - joyful - sad'.

sections.title: Word Families
sections.what: Word families are groups like act, action, actor, active.
sections.tutorial: Group related words in a <ul> and explain root word in <p>.
sections.steps:
1. Start with root word: act.
  2. Add: actor, acting, action.
  3. Explain each.

sections.title: English Reading Comprehension - Part IV
sections.what: This section teaches how to read and understand texts better.
sections.tutorial: Display a short passage in <p> and ask questions using <ol>.
sections.steps:
1. Write a short story or paragraph.
  2. Ask 3â€“5 questions after it using <ol> and <li>.
  3. Highlight answers below.

sections.title: Main Idea and Details
sections.what: The main idea is the overall point; details support it.
sections.tutorial: Use <strong> to mark the main idea and <ul> for details.
sections.steps:
1. Show paragraph.
  2. Highlight sentence as main idea.
  3. List details under it.

sections.title: Inference and Context Clues
sections.what: Inference means guessing meaning based on clues; context helps define unknown words.
sections.tutorial: Use short passages in <p> and bold the word to infer. Give options in <ul>.
sections.steps:
1. Show sentence with unknown word.
  2. Provide 3 meanings to choose from.
  3. Explain why the correct one fits.
